utterances: Tribes are made up of families, and families know their own history.
Reynold Leno is tribal council chairman.
And when you have people that don't kind of fit into that family-type scenario, it kind of draws a question.
And I think that's what a lot of people wanted looked into.
Leno wouldn't discuss pending cases, but he says the audit was needed to correct inconsistencies in the tribal record.
And while he says any disenrollments that result from that are unfortunate, he says the tribe has a constitution, and it's his job to uphold it.
Right now...
No, we don't.
We try to be budget conscious, and we have a lot of midsize cars.

But a good thing for them to have, actually, is an accounting background in white-collar fraud, you know, understanding how to follow records, bank accounts, corporations, shell companies, which we'll see in this type of work.
Back in his days of field work, Lester Davis once cracked a case of a man who had 73 aliases and got hold of 100 properties with mortgages insured by the government.
It started on a very, very small complaint that came in, and then we saw the name again, and at that point, we saw five, six properties that may be associated.
Then we started using the techniques.
We started using databases that can tie in nexuses to addresses, names, aliases.
We started running all those out, and it took us about six months to find this guy.
He was very, very good.
But Lester Davis says not every criminal starts out with bad intentions.
In these tough economic times, the public servants who will be watching over the stimulus money might just get tempted.

What I've seen over the years - and this is the type of people we're talking about here - is they take a little bit to make that mortgage payment, take a little bit to make a payment on something else.
Nobody notices, and they're still falling behind, take a little more.
They often keep track of what they've taken, and in their mind, I'm going to pay it back.
I'm going to pay it back.
But they don't get around to paying it back because it gets too big.
Do you think in general, white-collar crime is on the rise?
Well, I can only speak for my department.
I know that every year, we get questionnaires from Justice asking that question.
I've just never seen it going down.
Let me say that.
In my 22 years, we've never been able to do all the work we have, and it's even more so now.
Lester Davis and his team have to watch more than 3,000 public housing authorities.
They range in size.
Los Angeles City Housing Authority will get more than $25 million of stimulus money.
Meanwhile, the housing authority in Beemer, Nebraska, will receive $27,000.
What to do?
A place like Beemer, with the $27,000, we're obviously not going to send any agents out there, auditors just to look at that, but you've got to make priorities, you know?
And you happen to think that $25 million is more important than $27,000, huh?
I would say we have got to put our resources where we can get the best result to the taxpayers.
That said, in the inspector general's most recent report to Congress, HUD said its investigators recovered some 60 million bucks in the last six-month reporting period.
As far as the stimulus money goes, Davis has to wait for that money to be spent and maybe misspent.
We're probably, on the investigative side, a year, two years away from seeing, you know, a lot of work.
That's why we're going to spend the first six months to a year going out there and talking.
Talking and trying to convince anyone tempted that fraud can mean the slammer.
(Soundbite of cell door closing)
Since Lester Davis decided it wouldn't be cost efficient to send a special agent to Beemer, Nebraska, we thought we'd pick up the slack.
I like to get my money's worth for things.
This is Annette Baush, executive director of the Beemer Housing Authority in Beemer, Nebraska, population 696.
Baush will be responsible for spending that $27,000.
She says Beemer plans to re-shingle their public housing apartments.
Can we trust Baush?
I am 65 years old.
I have been working with Beemer Housing Authority for 21 years.
So, I just work part time, and that fits into my volunteer schedule.
Volunteer, huh?
Sounds suspicious.
I do quite a bit of church work.
I deliver Meals on Wheels occasionally.
I do the school census and things like that.
Okay.
So, Lester Davis, maybe you can cross the housing authority of Beemer, Nebraska, off your watch list.
That leaves only $3,609,973,000 to worry about.
We're keeping an eye on you.
(Soundbite of music)
It's MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
And I'm Lynn Neary.
Pakistan's President Pervez Musharraf is saying that in the days after September 11th, the United States threatened to bomb his country if he didn't go along with the war on terror.
He made those remarks in an interview scheduled to air Sunday on the CBS news program 60 Minutes.
Since September 11th, Pakistan has become a key U.S.
ally in the war on terrorism.
President Bush is meeting with President Musharraf this morning.
Well, Iraq almost doesn't count.
You know, there's always potential problems in Iraq.
(Soundbite of laughter)
That's NPR congressional reporter Kelsey Snell.
But both in and outside of Oregon, disenrollments are raising questions.
David Wilkins is a professor of American Indian Studies at the University of Minnesota and a member of the Lumbee Nation.
He estimates as many as 8,000 U.S.
citizens have been cast out of native tribes over the last two decades, and Wilkins worries disenrollments could be putting tribal autonomy in jeopardy.

At some point, there's going to be enough clamor raised by disenrollees that there is going to be a congressional hearing, or there is going to be a Supreme Court decision that might seriously impinge on what is a true sine qua non of a sovereign nation - that is, the power to decide who belongs.
Jade Unger acknowledges he might lose his federally recognized status, but he says nobody can take away his identity as a native person.
That's, hands down, way more important to me than any little, you know, chunk of money I might get in a per capita payment.
I don't care about that.
I care about my tribe.
You know, I feel like I belong.
We belong.
And Unger says that's the one thing he wants to hold onto.
For NPR News, I'm David Nogueras in Bend, Oregon.
For almost a decade, the National Security Agency has been collecting the phone records of nearly every American.
This became public two years ago with the leaks from former NSA contractor Edward Snowden.
Well, now a federal appeals court says that bulk collection program is illegal.
The decision comes as there's a looming deadline for Congress to decide the fate of the program.
NPR's David Welna reports.
The ruling that a three-judge panel from New York's Second Circuit Appeals Court issued today was fairly narrow in scope but possibly huge in its impact.
It did not decide whether the NSA's massive collection of Americans' phone records violates the Constitution.
It simply said that the bulk collection of those records exceeds what Congress authorized in the Patriot Act and is therefore illegal.
I think it should end any debate about whether this particular program is lawful or not.
That's the American Civil Liberties Union's Jameel Jaffer.
He's the lead counsel in this case brought against the nation's top security officials.
Jaffer concedes that he would've liked a court injunction as well that would have ordered the government to stop the NSA's ongoing bulk collection program.
We would prefer that there be an injunction like that, but to tell you the truth, you know, the main goal of the litigation was to get a ruling of exactly the kind we got today.
So we're very pleased with it.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
